@Sathiamurthi Mahalingam technical questions are usually raised on #implementers or more specific streams. You can look for guidance on mapping to and from C-CDA in the: #CCDA / FHIR mapping stream and in this IG: http://hl7.org/fhir/us/ccda/STU1.1

Hi ,
I create application in Fhir. I want to access token from server. when i request it shows response like INVALID CLIENT.i create keypairs using openssl and created jwt by header type as jwt and Algorithm as RS384 and also payload as iss,sub,iat,aud,exp,jti and also signature publickey and private key as openssl created keys.it shows INVALID CLIENT. please help me for getting access token
Hi Gowtham, welcome to the community! We are using this #social stream for general discussions, so your question would probably get answers quicker in the #implementers or #smart streams!
@Gowtham Also, it would be helpful to understand what system you're trying to access.

Hello all, I am new and just learning HL7/FHIR. I come from a web app developer background using LAMP stacks and GraphQL/React/Next.JS I was interested in the GraphQL side of things with regards to FHIR and graph databases. Are there people in this community using GraphQL or a graph database (Dgraph, Neo4j, Neptune, etc.) It seems to me the FHIR spec including the flatten directive breaks the official GraphQL spec, so I am interested in a discussion around this topic if there is anyone interested.

Welcome to the community :)
GraphQL folks hang out here: #graphql
Discussions related to FHIR storage (graph-based or otherwise) tend to be here: #storage for FHIR
perfect! Thank you!

Hi All, Sorry if this is the wrong place to post my message but in general I am trying to understand how is SMART on FHIR different from FHIR? Lets say, I want to integrate my App in a couple different EHRs, should I directly use FHIR APIs exposed by the EHR or go through SMART and what are the advantages of using SMART over directly calling EHR FHR endpoints.
FHIR is an interoperability specification for healthcare data. Oversimplified, SMART on FHIR is a OAuth specification that handles authentication and authorization for FHIR servers.
Thanks David for a prompt response. Does SMART also handles App registration and other overhead with EHRs or is it something we've to deal with EHR separately.
You're probably better off reading through the intro to the spec, which is here: https://hl7.org/fhir/smart-app-launch/

Detailed discussion on SMART on FHIR can also happen here: #smart. Essentially SMART on FHIR leverages FHIR for data access, but adds an additional framework on top of it to manage app launch, permissions, identity verification and authorization.
Thanks Lloyd, this is super helpful. Does that mean Redox type of middleware vendors would loose ground given SMART is open source and free?

My guess is that having more data available through open standards will help all integrators move "up the value chain" (e.g., focusing on data types or workflows that aren't well standardized yet, or creation of services that make it easier to work with the data --- quality assessment assessment/improvement, orchestration, deduplication/cleanup, classification, and on and on.) We have plenty of problems to solve, and I see standards as a rising tide that lifts all the boats.
Deleted

Hi, I recently started looking into FHIR. I am confused looking at the encounter profile(http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/encounter.html). From my understanding, the property 'type' of encounter has a set of values given in http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/valueset-encounter-type.html . But some examples have a different value other than this set. Look at this example (http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/encounter-example-f203-20130311.json.html). How is this possible? Thanks

Hi & welcome :wave: (BTW questions are best asked in the #implementers stream). Your are right that Encounter.type has a binding to the value set you mention. However, the binding only has the strength "example". That means that there is no requirement (or even expectation) that instances will use codes from this set - it is merely way of indicating what kind of codes might be used in this element. To enforce the use of certain codes in an element, one needs a required or extensible binding - see the documentation of binding strengths.
Thank you so much for the quick turnaround. That explanation helps.
Greger George has marked this topic as resolved.

Hi everyone this is my first open source project, so can anyone tell me that from where should i contribute in this project as a newbie, Excited to be part of it and work with this community

@Yash Giradkar There are a variety of ways to contribute. You can provide feedback on the core specification or most implementation guides using the 'propose a change' link at the bottom of each page. You can decide to get involved with one or more of the work groups that help define and maintain the content (the responsible work group is a link on most pages in the core spec and generally in the footer of implementation guides. You can get involved in supporting one or more of the reference implementations or other tools the community has created. And of course, you can go forth and create tools of your own. So your first decision is: how do you want to get involved? :) Welcome.
@Lloyd McKenzie thanks sir for providing me information and i will find ways to get involved in this project

@Francis Otieno FYI re. GSOC

Hey FHIR community geeks! I am from India and very new here. I am doing information architecture modelling for a large global compliance organisation. I looked at the FHIR spec and am very impressed with the layered architecture documentation (Layers & level ) and the description, diagrams and specs for each of the resources. I was keen to understand if we could use the Publishing infrastructure to create private/proprietary models in much the same manner as FHIR does.... I do understand that the publishing tools is released under CC, so it should not be an issue. Just wanted the experts view on this .... how easy of difficult it is to develop and publish Private models , including how the various diagrams are created , UML/XML i.e. Resource Content and other descriptive information about a resource. Would be great if someone could advice on it. Much thanks in advance

Using the publication machinery for the core spec probably wouldn't work very well. There's a whole lot of code that is specific to certain resources, data types, etc. and it would be difficult to make it work. However, you could probably create a publication that looked quite similar using the ImplementationGuide publisher tool and define all of your proprietary models as FHIR logical models. We don't currently generate diagrams for logical models, but that's something we could (and probably should) add.
